results.abstract: Roundup of summer theater, dance and music festivals around US and Canada; drawings; photos (L)

headline.main: Warm Weather Destinations: A Nation of Stages

results.snippet: THEATER  Following is a selected list, compiled by Anna Bahney, of events through September. Performances rarely occur every day of the week, and programs are subject to change.    Alabama    ALABAMA SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL -- Montgomery....
results.lead_paragraph: THEATER Following is a selected list, compiled by Anna Bahney, of events through September. Performances rarely occur every day of the week, and programs are subject to change. Alabama ALABAMA SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL -- Montgomery. (800-841-4273). Productions in two theaters. Festival Stage: May 21-July 27: ''Much Ado About Nothing.'' June 11-July 28: ''Hamlet.'' Aug. 2-Sept. 1: Reduced Shakespeare Company's ''Reducers.'' Octagon Theater: May 14-July 27: premiere of ''Shiloh Rules'' by Doris Baizley. June 4-July 28: ''Sheppy'' by Somerset Maugham. Aug. 6-17: ''Merry Wives of Windsor'' with the Graduate Acting Company. www.asf.net

results.abstract: Houston Astros defeat New York Mets, 3-1; photo (M)

headline.main: Vaughn and the Mets Trying to Find Their Swing

results.snippet: Mo Vaughn had logged countless hours watching videotape, comparing his swing with past years. Everything was the same, but he could not figure out why he was not driving the ball.    Finally, Vaughn left an early session in the indoor batting cage...
results.lead_paragraph: Mo Vaughn had logged countless hours watching videotape, comparing his swing with past years. Everything was the same, but he could not figure out why he was not driving the ball. Finally, Vaughn left an early session in the indoor batting cage today, took his bat and placed it on a scale inside the Mets' clubhouse. Aha! Vaughn's bat was heavier than he was used to.

results.abstract: Article on report issued by National Research Council, requested by National Aeronautics and Space Administration, on hazards to humans of mission to Mars; biggest concern for human travel to Mars, unlikely for at least two or three decades, is question of toxic metals in Martian soil and windblown dust; photo; diagram (M)

headline.main: A Head Start on Potential Hazards for Mars Explorers

results.snippet: No little green men will be lurking behind boulders, ready to zap all comers with their deadly ray guns. But that hardly means the first humans to visit Mars will have nothing to fear. It is not too soon, scientists say, to start worrying about the...
results.lead_paragraph: No little green men will be lurking behind boulders, ready to zap all comers with their deadly ray guns. But that hardly means the first humans to visit Mars will have nothing to fear. It is not too soon, scientists say, to start worrying about the potential Martian menace of killer dust. Scientists studying the risks facing human explorers of Mars have cautioned that windblown dust, pervasive on the arid planet, threatens to abrade, clog and corrode vital spacecraft systems. And some of the dust breathed by astronauts may contain one of the most toxic chemicals known, the cancer-causing hexavalent chromium.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour is set to lift off on 12-day mission to deliver new crew to International Space Station and install critical components of station's $600 million robotic arm; astronauts will also try to fix problem on one of arm's wrist joints, a repair deemed critical to completing girder-like central truss (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Flight Today to Carry New Crew to Space Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour is to lift off on Thursday on a 12-day mission to deliver a new crew to the International Space Station and install critical components of the station's $600 million robotic arm.    Citing security after Sept. 11, the...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour is to lift off on Thursday on a 12-day mission to deliver a new crew to the International Space Station and install critical components of the station's $600 million robotic arm. Citing security after Sept. 11, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration withheld the liftoff time, 7:44 p.m., until late this afternoon. Stormy weather could keep the shuttle grounded until next week.
